awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Search-Based Optimization of Combinatorial Structures via Expensive Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
Many design-optimization problems in science and engineering applications involve performing experiments that are expensive in terms of the consumed resources (computational or physical). These experiments are often guided by intuition and performed by human engineers and scientists in an series of investigations informed by results of prior experiments. This experimental design process can be very challenging when the design space is combinatorial with rich structure among the design variables (e.g., sets, sequences, and graphs). This five-year project is an integrated research, education, and outreach program focused on transforming the practice of optimizing combinatorial design spaces by developing new artificial intelligence (AI) based algorithms for such experiments. 

The research goal of this project is to develop a new search-based learning and optimization framework to address the challenges associated with optimizing combinatorial design spaces consisting of discrete and hybrid (mixture of discrete and continuous design variables) structures. This framework tightly integrates advances in machine learning and AI search to intelligently explore the design space by reasoning about the available resource budget and the usefulness of potential information the experiments may provide. The search-based framework will be extended to two novel settings towards the goal of improving the resource-efficiency for design optimization. First, the side-information generated by the experiments will be modeled and exploited appropriately. Second, multi-fidelity experiments that trade off accuracy and consumed resources will be leveraged based on their availability. The project will apply the developed algorithms to revolutionize the areas of electronic design automation, design of materials, and design of synthetic microbiomes via close collaboration with domain experts from these application areas. The techniques developed in this project will be made available to academia and industry through open-source software. Results will be disseminated widely through research papers, conference presentations, tutorials, and short courses to maximize the benefits to the scientific community. Educational and outreach activities will include a novel Ambassador program to improve the interest of community college students including under-represented minorities in computer science careers; involving undergraduate students in research projects; a short summer-course on data-driven design optimization for engineers and scientists at WSU; and recruiting and mentoring under-represented minority groups in computer science and engineering through an existing program called LSAMP at Washington State University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many design-optimization problems in science and engineering applications involve performing experiments that are expensive in terms of the consumed resources (computational or physical). These experiments are often guided by intuition and performed by human engineers and scientists in an series of investigations informed by results of prior experiments. This experimental design process can be very challenging when the design space is combinatorial with rich structure among the design variables (e.g., sets, sequences, graphs, and mixture of continuous and discrete variables). The overarching goal of this CAREER project is to transform the practice of optimizing combinatorial design spaces by developing new artificial intelligence (AI) based algorithms for such experiments.


The intellectual merits of the work was to significantly advance the theory and practice of AI-driven adaptive experimental design to accelerate engineering design and scientific discovery. We developed novel machine learning (ML) based surrogate models for fixed-size discrete structures, varying-sized combinatorial structures (e.g., graphs), and hybrid structures (mixture of discrete and continuous variables). We also developed tools that enable the use of state-of-the-art decision policies for single objective optimization to handle combinatorial spaces. Another key innovation was to develop a information-theoretic framework to select experiments for solving a large-class of multi-objective optimization problems in different settings including experiments with different accuracy and resource cost trade-offs, handling hard constraints that cannot be evaluated without performing experiments, and limited experimental resource budget. Another approach was to select experiments to prioritize resources where they yield the most value to efficiently learn the importance of different input variables for expensive black-box functions (aka global sensitivity analysis). We also developed a learning-to-search framework to select the most promising combinatorial experiment guided by any complex surrogate model. Throughout the project new benchmarks and software were created for the research community to support further work by other researchers.


The broader impact of the project was to investigate the application of the developed adaptive experimental design algorithms for a variety of engineering and scientific applications. This included work on reducing the number of experiments for designing high-performance and energy-efficient hardware accelerators for AI workloads, discovery of nanoporous materials for sustainability applications, biological sequence design for health applications, design of electric transportation power systems, and optimizing the parameters of a 3D printing process to trade-off accuracy and throughput. The project trained three PhD students to perform inter-disciplinary research who joined the scientific workforce as tenure-track faculty at University of Minnesota, data science postdoctoral fellow at Stanford University, and research scientist at Meta Research respectively. The PI and PhD students on this project delivered well-recieved tutorials at major AI/ML conferences, taught a short course on data-driven design optimization for engineers and scientists at WSU, and organized a successful annual AAAI workshop on AI to Accelerate Science and Engineering with diverse themes including chemistry, earth and environmental sciences, and biological sciences.
